articles.headline: Democrats Gain as Stevens Loses Race
articles.snippet: Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, convicted on federal ethics charges, lost his bid for a seventh term, giving Democrats at least 58 seats in the Senate.
articles.abstract: Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, convicted on federal ethics charges, lost his bid for a seventh term, giving Democrats at least 58 seats in the Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, convicted last month on federal ethics charges, lost his bid for a seventh term as final ballots were counted on Tuesday, giving Democrats at least 58 seats in the Senate for the first years of the Obama administration.

articles.headline: Detroit Chiefs Plead for Aid
articles.snippet: The Big Three automakers asked for help to stave off collapse, but it appeared they had not persuaded enough lawmakers to move quickly on a bailout.
articles.abstract: The Big Three automakers asked for help to stave off collapse, but it appeared they had not persuaded enough lawmakers to move quickly on a bailout.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The heads of the Big Three automakers of Detroit pleaded on Tuesday for emergency government aid to stave off potential collapse, but after four hours of testimony, it appeared they had not persuaded enough lawmakers to move quickly on a bailout.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Advantage of Corporate Bankruptcy Is Dwindling
articles.snippet: More companies that file for bankruptcy protection are shutting down because they cannot obtain enough financing to operate while they reorganize.
articles.abstract: More companies that file for bankruptcy protection are shutting down because they cannot obtain enough financing to operate while they reorganize.
articles.lead_paragraph: Harsh as it is, a bankruptcy filing has always offered a glimmer of hope for a business hobbled by debt or a downturn. A company could slim down, negotiate manageable payments to workers and suppliers and keep going, preserving jobs.

articles.headline: Now Comes the Hard Part as Yahoo Wrestles With a Question of Direction
articles.snippet: Does Yahoo want to remain independent or should it sell some or all of itself to another Internet player?
articles.abstract: Does Yahoo want to remain independent or should it sell some or all of itself to another Internet player?
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  There’s a new parlor game in Silicon Valley: guessing who will replace Jerry Yang at the helm of the troubled Internet giant Yahoo.

articles.headline: Piling Up Monuments of Waste
articles.snippet: When it comes to the nation’s infrastructure, money isn’t the main problem. The bigger problem has been an utter lack of seriousness in deciding how that money gets spent.
articles.abstract: When it comes to the nation’s infrastructure, money isn’t the main problem. The bigger problem has been an utter lack of seriousness in deciding how that money gets spent.

articles.headline: Britain Grapples With Role for Islamic Justice
articles.snippet: Conservatives and liberals have denounced Islamic courts as poor substitutes for British jurisprudence.
articles.abstract: Conservatives and liberals have denounced Islamic courts as poor substitutes for British jurisprudence.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  The woman in black wanted an Islamic divorce. She told the religious judge that her husband hit her, cursed her and wanted her dead.

articles.headline: Holder Seen as Obama Choice for Justice Post
articles.snippet: Barack Obama’s transition team has signaled to Eric H. Holder Jr. that he will be chosen as attorney general, but no final decision has been made, people involved in the process said.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama’s transition team has signaled to Eric H. Holder Jr. that he will be chosen as attorney general, but no final decision has been made, people involved in the process said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President-elect Barack Obama’s transition team has signaled to Eric H. Holder Jr., a senior official in the Justice Department in the Clinton administration, that he will be chosen as attorney general, but no final decision has been made, people involved in the process said Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and John M. Broder

articles.headline: A Sea of Unwanted Imports
articles.snippet: Unwelcome by dealers and buyers, thousands of cars are being warehoused on crowded port property, creating a vivid picture of a paralyzed auto business.
articles.abstract: Unwelcome by dealers and buyers, thousands of cars are being warehoused on crowded port property, creating a vivid picture of a paralyzed auto business.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONG BEACH, Calif.  Gleaming new Mercedes cars roll one by one out of a huge container ship here and onto a pier. Ordinarily the cars would be loaded on trucks within hours, destined for dealerships around the country. But these are not ordinary times.

articles.headline: Shares Near 6-Year Low, With More Losses Feared
articles.snippet: As the stock market tumbled to its lowest level in nearly six years, traders and many others were asking the same question: Where is the bottom?
articles.abstract: As the stock market tumbled to its lowest level in nearly six years, traders and many others were asking the same question: Where is the bottom?
articles.lead_paragraph: As the stock market tumbled to its lowest level in nearly six years on Wednesday, Wall Street traders and many ordinary Americans were asking the same question: Where, oh where is the bottom?

articles.headline: Stocks Are Hurt by Latest Fear: Declining Prices
articles.snippet: The Dow fell below 8,000 as concern spread that the economy might be facing a chronic and debilitating decline in prices.
articles.abstract: The Dow fell below 8,000 as concern spread that the economy might be facing a chronic and debilitating decline in prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: After gyrating wildly for weeks, the stock market lurched lower on Wednesday, falling to its lowest point in nearly six years, as concern spread that the economy might be facing a chronic and debilitating decline in prices.

articles.headline: Auto Chiefs Fail to Get Bailout Aid
articles.snippet: The Big Three automakers left Washington empty-handed after two days of pleading for a financial lifeline.
articles.abstract: The Big Three automakers left Washington empty-handed after two days of pleading for a financial lifeline.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The chief executives of Detroit’s Big Three automakers departed Washington empty-handed on Wednesday night after two days of pleading for a financial lifeline on Capitol Hill.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and David M. Herszenhorn
